prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The requested spectral resolution allows us to spectrally resolve 1 km/s lines, which is the expected minimum line width for these disks based on similar observations of TW Hya.

The requested angular resolution allows us to fit 4 beams inside the predicted snow line radius (see Table 1). The request largest angular scale is 3 beams beyond the snow line. This insures we are able to resolve and snow line and allows for some uncertainty in the location of the snow line.

The expected peak flux is calculated by scaling the peak 13CO flux per beam observed in TW Hya to the desired beam size for this source, assuming the emission falls off linearly. The desired sensitivity is that needed to detect the faint 13CO emission beyond the snow line at the 3 sigma level. The continuum flux density is scaled from continuum observations at 1.3 mm. The bandwidth has been decreased to be under the data rate limit.

The desired sensitivity is that needed to detect the faint 13CO emission beyond the snow line at the 3 sigma level. The continuum flux density is scaled from continuum observations at 860 microns. The bandwidth has been decreased to be under the data rate limit.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Snow lines, the location is a protoplanetary disk where a molecule condenses onto grains, are theroized to play an important role in planet formation, aiding the growth of planetesimals as well as modifying the relative abundance of volatile elements, e.g. C and O, both on grains and in the gas. In order to observationally study the effect of these features it is first necessary to resolve their location in the disk. Recently, we have found a way to directly observe the CO snow line using J=6-5 emission of CO isotopes. Here, we propose to resolve the CO snow line in 9 protoplanetary disks with a a range of ages and stellar spectral types using 13CO, C18O, and C17O J=6-5.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
